data.title: Ability to add links to diagnostics and render them as links in problems view

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
For example, linting `var test = 1` results in these warnings in the Problems panel: ![2016-09-11_185535](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/723651/18418560/614fcde8-7851-11e6-95e1-eb620d3ef8c2.jpg) My suggestion: the `no-unused-vars` and `semi` to be clickable and to link to http://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-unused-vars and to http://eslint.org/docs/rules/semi respectively. _(I've found this feature in AtomLinter and it's really useful)_ cc: @dbaeumer
PS. Using vscode-eslint 1.10.18 with ESLint 3.5.0 in VSCode 1.5.1 using win10 x64.

data.title: Show known file types for file "open" dialog boxes

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hi, I want to suggest a feature for a next VSCode version. 

The current version of the software doesn't allow to filter the files by type, when we pick up a file to open it. We also can't select its extension when we save it (we are obliged to add the extension suffix to the filename). 

So, I think it is a good idea to add this two functionalities to VSCode.

data.title: How to increase the font size of IntelliSense panel?
data.body:
Hi, I want to increase the font size of the IntelliSense panel (I don't know exactly what's its name so I will call that, you can see more details in the image) but I don't know how because my current font size is quite small, does vscode have an option for that?

![Font size too small](http://i.imgur.com/Hm6F2Lm.png)

data.title: wrapping column not always shown depending on zoom level

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: Linux Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  In the settings, enable wrapping like with "rewrap.wrappingColumn": 80,
2. Restart.
3. Note the line showing the 80th character column will show.
4. Zoom out. Note that the wrapping line is no longer showin.
5. Zoom out again. Wrapping line is now showing.
6. Now if you continue zooming out, the wrapping line never show.

It only shows up with two level of zoom (default, and 2 times out)

# \- VSCode Version: 1.5.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. open file search window (command+p)
2. input something 

I can not get any file search result in my project  after updating The latest version of vscode(1.5.1).

And i noticed that when i am typing some keyword of file name ,CODE will generate some subprocess do these search job with  `80 percent of the CPU cost`

data.title: Strange cursor behavior after workspace.applyEdit();
Dislike default toggled find in selection
data.body:
I would like this to either be turned off by default or to always allow the current selection to be cleared via clicking within the text body.

I do _not_ want to go click the little box to turn off _find in selection_ every time I select, copy, and paste something into find/replace.

Another solution for me would be to provide an option in the settings for one of the above solutions.

(Or let me know if there is already a setting available that I missed while searching.)

data.title: Refactor terminal to enable processes to exist without the panel
data.body:
The goals for this refactor are:
- To separate terminal instances/processes from the terminal panel so the former can exist without the latter (#11384, #11275)
- Push as much instance related logic down to the service
- Have nothing rely on the panel
- Make writing automated tests easier

data.title: Trigger language auto detection mechanism
data.body:
Some times I'm fetching some content from the web and pasting it into the current active editor.
So far, I didn't find any way to set the current language for the window. Is there any particular API call for that?

Even better, would it be possible to trigger the auto detection mechanism with the API?

data.title: Prevent startup access to 238.172.191
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: Win 7 Home Pro 64

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Configure all privacy options to false as per [https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs#privacy](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs#privacy)
2. Block VSCode at firewall
3. Start VSCode
4. VSCode reports 'connect EACCES 191.238.172.191:443' error

I would like to be able to control internet access without having this error message. This problem did not occur in VSCode 1.4. It would be good if there was a privacy setting to prevent this attempted access.

data.title: make suggest list supports fuzzy matching
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5

> For example, searching `view_cn` brings up `view_class_name`.

For example, create a new document:

```
django
view_class
view_class_name
view
    ^
```

After typing `view`, the suggest list will appear ([`view_class`, `view_class_name`]), but VSCode does not support continue type a `n` to filter down this list to [`view_class_name`].

Atom has this feature:
![atom-complete](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8944061/18414214/72aa691c-77f3-11e6-90a7-7afca277205b.png)

data.title: 1.5.1 .deb package misses depencies
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu GNU/Linux 16.04

Summary: VSCode package for Ubuntu 16.04 requires several i386 packages to be installed on the system, but does not specify them as a dependency. End result is `code` not running due to missing dependencies, even though the package installs without error.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install the .deb package
2. Open a terminal
3. Run `code`

Expected result: VSCode opens up

Actual result: Missing dependencies:

```
mverwijs@x230 ~> code
/usr/share/code/bin/../code: error while loading shared libraries: libgtk-x11-2.0.so.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

mverwijs@x230 ~> code
/usr/share/code/bin/../code: error while loading shared libraries: libXtst.so.6: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

mverwijs@x230 ~> code
/usr/share/code/bin/../code: error while loading shared libraries: libgconf-2.so.4: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

```

Workaround: 

```
sudo apt-get install libgtk2.0-0:i386 libxtst6:i386 libgconf-2-4:i386
```

data.title: Debug Console doesn't scroll when starting empty
data.body: Start debugging with the console empty. When output reaches the bottom of the console, it won't scroll with the output. If you scroll all the way down, then it will continue to scroll with the output. I think a regression after the smart-scroll change.

data.title: Linux version cannot autofill DOCTYPE
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04, 64 bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start Visual Studio Code.
2. Create an empty HTML file.
3. Input `<!DOC` for example.
4. Press TAB.
5. It should fill with the form below but nothing happens.

```
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>Document</title>
</head>
<body>

</body>
</html>
```

2. Expand directories in the right hand side page, noticed how the files seem to be indented too much of the left hand side.

data.title: Column mode selection behavior is inconsistent with user expectations
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04, Windows 7/10, probably all others

Most programs with column mode (visual studio/notepad++/kdevelop/etc) have the following user experience:
1. hold the keyboard shortcut/toggle column mode.
2. click somewhere. This is the selection 'start' anchor.
3. drag somewhere. This is the selection 'end' anchor.

However, in visual studio code, the process is:
1. click somewhere. This is the selection 'start' anchor.
2. hold the keyboard shortcut/toggle column mode
3. drag somewhere. This is the selection 'end' anchor.

IMHO this is unintuitive for two reasons:
1. It goes against all the training we have from other dev tools we've been using much longer.
2. Usually, I don't think about where I _left_ my cursor when I decide to do an operation. I'm thinking about what I _want_ to do. I find that whenever I use code's column mode, I'm always unpleasantly surprised to find that the cursor is not where I expect it and isn't updated to my click.

Additionally, while it's technically the same number of steps, method 1 is much more fluid as the holding/clicking/dragging can be done in a smooth motion, rather than having to position the cursor as a distinct and thoughtful first step.

Could you please change the cursor selection to method 2?

data.title: `ESC` key no longer closes the output window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.5.1 (07d663dc1bd848161edf4cd4ce30cce410d3d877, 2016-09-08T21:33:49.307Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run any sort of code (in my case Golang code) and watch the "Output" window pop up with the program output
2. Press `ESC` to close the window; it doesn't work.
3. This was working fine before the latest update so possibly a regression?

data.title: [json] validation doesn't work offline

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.3

Every time I launch VS Code when I'm offline, I get this error:

![2016-09-10-1wv8p](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1612675/18410407/da0e188a-776a-11e6-8313-c3fc75765132.png)

JSON validation doesn't work as a result.
I hope a schema reference can be initially cached inside the editor and downloaded once again when internet is on.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Go offline (switch off the internet)
2. Open VS Code.
3. Open some `json` file
4. Work without validation but with an error.

data.title: git repos not detected in sub-folders of the open folder
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: macOS, Windows 10

If you add a folder that contains multiple folders of git repos, the git integration does not work.  It only seems to work if you open a folder that is a git repo directly (and then it's pretty brilliant).

It would be great if the root didn't need to be a repo, but Code were intelligent enough to detect that sub-folders contain different repos and still have all the features work.

data.title: Ability to add multiple open folders to a single project
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: macOS

Feature Request

It would be nice to be able to add / remove multiple folders to / from a project, not unlike Sublime Text. (Gif attached).

![multiple-folders](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1939040/18410253/d9c6e068-772a-11e6-9d2b-1685493f660a.gif)

This is one of the few things keeping a number of people I know from using Code, and to be honest as much as Code is killing it right now, this is one of the missing features keeping me from using it for all of my editing.

data.title: Text selection finished above Terminal Window makes loosing focus on Editor Window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.5.1 (1.5.1) 07d663dc1bd848161edf4cd4ce30cce410d3d877 2016-09-08T21:25:39.888Z
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.6 (15G1004)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have a source editor with some file (tried with js, css) and the internal terminal open
2. Start selecting a text block with track pad, tap and start dragging selection
3. While selecting move pointer above terminal window
4. Finish selecting text by pulling up finger from track pad - make sure you are above terminal window

Expected:
Text is selected and source editor in focus, so next key press will overwrite selection

Actual:
Text is selected but internal terminal window is in focus, so next key press will not overwrite selection, but will input a character in terminal.

Note: When the same steps tried with explorer window instead of terminal, it works as expected. Low priority.
